pr_title: Log and explicitly send 404 in get datastream rest call

timeline.message:
Log and explicitly send 404 in get datastream call

DatastreamResources get call doesnt not log an error when stream is not
found. This is not consistent with other APIs. Make it consistent with
the rest of the APIs which allows for also logging in case stream is not
found and can be helpful with debugging. Change also removes the logging
of time it takes for the get also for consistency. It is not a batch
operation and doesn't seem like it warrants a log for execution time.

timeline.bodyText: nit: maybe we should keep this log? That Get was called? I know that I've used this log for other operations we perform (stop, resume, pause, etc), and it may be helpful to know if the server is receiving Get requests or not if we see some failures.
timeline.author: somandal

timeline.bodyText:
I scoured Rest.li's docs and source code to see if throwing an exception was idiomatic for 404s. The javadocs of this method in one of the parent types of DatastreamResources, i.e. CollectionResource, states that null is expected in case the resource isn't found:
  /**
   * Gets this resource.
   *
   * @param key resource key
   * @return null if resource was not found
   */
  V get(K key);

Throwing a RestLiServiceException seems to be intended for unexpected server errors.
I think we can just adjust logging in the current code to print whether a datastream was found or not.
timeline.author: ahmedahamid

replies.bodyText:
Makes sense. I reverted the change to throw. But what counts for unexpected server errors? For example the delete API doc says
   * Deletes this resource.
   *
   * @param key resource key
   * @return the status or null if for a default, 204 No Content response
   */

Does that mean, other APIs also should be returning a null when the look up of the stream to operate on fails?
replies.author: DEEPTHIKORAT

replies.bodyText:
But what counts for unexpected server errors?

Getting a network exception, interrupted exception, failing to find a required file on disk, no permission to access resource ... etc — situations where your web-app is running into an unexpected problem.

Does that mean, other APIs also should be returning a null when the look up of the stream to operate on fails?

Rest.li seems to interpret null differently for the different HTTP verbs. In the case of delete for instance, returning null actually indicates success. 204 is a success code. This is why the method you referenced offers the convenience of returning null if you want to say deletion was successful, instead of having to construct an UpdateResponse with a 204 status code yourself.
Accordingly, our DatastreamResources.delete(), for example, should just return an UpdateResponse with a 404 status code if a datastream isn't found instead of throwing; there's no service error in this case.
replies.author: ahmedahamid

replies.bodyText:
I looked into Rest.li's source code and here is what I found:

Rest.li translates a null return value into a 200 (OK) response for methods whose HTTP method is POST
It also translates a null return value into a 404 (NOT FOUND) response for methods whose HTTP method is GET

However, it does not translate null for methods whose HTTP method is DELETE (e.g. DatastreamResources.delete()). So, we can't return null to indicate success from a delete method. We'd have to return UpdateResponse(HttpStatus.S_404_NOT_FOUND).
But everything we've discussed so far still holds.
replies.author: ahmedahamid

replies.bodyText:
Just documenting a conversation you and I had offline in case anyone refers to this thread in the future.
You brought it to my attention that the the same piece of code I referenced did actually throw a RestLiServiceException when translating null from GET methods into 404 (code). I looked further and found that Rest.li translates all thrown RestLiServiceExceptions (code) for all HTTP verbs according to the status codes they carry, which invalidates the assumption I was making that these exceptions were reserved for internal server errors.
Out of consistency with our existing DatastreamResources.delete(), which throws if a datastream isn't found, we decided to keep the current logic in your PR as is.
Please, excuse the back and forth. I am learning about Rest.li as we go.
replies.author: ahmedahamid
